entry.title: Re: Need a license key for an internal training IDES system
entry.content:
Dear customer,

In order to get an IDES license key, could you pls kindly refer to the following KBA for more detailed information and steps:

KBA 3451876 - How to request license key for IDES system 

"To request license key for IDES system, just follow the detailed steps as per KBA 2346021 and request the license key under customer's own technical installation number. "

Hope it helps. 

And should you have any further issue during the license key request, feel free to contact the license key support team by creating a case using component XX-SER-LIKEY. 

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Use of MDF Object in Variable Pay Employee History Rule
entry.content:
Hi Team,

In the Variable Pay template, the Employee History Rule is configured to bring in employees with ACTIVE status only, along with few other conditions like Bonus Plan = Annual Performance. We also have an MDF object created where we are storing an employee's information for excluding the employee's Unpaid Leave period (As there is no LOA/Time-off in EC). The rule is working fine and excluding the periods of Unpaid Leave as expected.

However, we also need to exclude the period when employee goes on Suspension (status = Suspended) in EC. System is behaving correctly and excluding the period of Suspension for few employees, specifically for those who have no record in MDF. But for those employees who do have a record in MDF, system is not able to identify the period of suspension and is still bringing it in EH section. 

Example Scenario:

Employee: ABC
Suspension Start Date in EC (Status = Suspended): 1 Feb 2024
Suspension End Date in EC (Status = Active): 29 Feb 2024
Unpaid Leave Start Date in MDF: 1 June 2024
Unpaid Leave End Date in MDF: 31 July 2024

Expected outcome was:

1st Jan - 31st Jan, 29th Feb - 31st May, 31st July to 31st Dec. However, system is not able to exclude the period of 1st Feb to 29th Feb from EH rule.

Could you please help as to what may be the issue here? Appreciate your guidance as always @xavierlegarrec

entry.title: Re: Workflow Configuration for SAP S/4HANA Sales Price
entry.content:
Hello all,

We don't support workflow condition based on product division and also don't support an attachment in the workflow email util now. If you have such requirement, you could create request from Customer Influence . Sorry for the late reply.

entry.title: Optimising Sourcing Cycle Times: How to Make It Stick
entry.content:
If you‚Äôre just joining, this post is part of a 3-part series  breaking down the why, what, and how of reducing sourcing cycle time. Make sure to check out Part 1: Why It Matters and Part 2: What to Fix to get the full picture.

 So far, we‚Äôve unpacked the why behind long sourcing cycles and shared what levers deliver results.  Now it‚Äôs time to zoom in on the how, not as a checklist, but as a transformation blueprint.  These are not quick fixes.  They‚Äôre layered, intentional moves that anchor speed, control, and intelligence deep into your sourcing DNA.

Realizing Value Isn‚Äôt About Tools, It‚Äôs About Adoption

Let‚Äôs get one thing clear: just buying a license to SAP Ariba or any best-in-class procurement platform doesn‚Äôt magically cut your cycle times in half.  The biggest difference I‚Äôve seen between customers who transform and those who stay stuck?  The activation of targeted capabilities with an outcome-driven mindset.

Think of it as the difference between owning a sports car and knowing how to drive it on a racetrack.  Reducing sourcing cycle time is not just a project, it‚Äôs a change journey across three parallel tracks:

  • Diagnose with Precision

Before enabling anything in your solution, think ‚Äòsurgically‚Äô about where your time is spent.

Run a discovery deep-dive:

  • Map every stage of your sourcing flow , intake, creation, approvals, award, contract.
  • Use SAP Ariba KPIs to benchmark:
    • Sourcing Cycle Time (Target: ‚â§11 days).
    • Events Awarded in Ariba (% of total).
    • Sourcing Events per Project Owner.

Use Signavio Process Intelligence to visualize bottlenecks and hidden friction:

  • Where are approvals piling up?
  • Which categories have the longest turnaround?
  • Are templates being reused or rebuilt each time?

Pro Tip: Layer on the SAP Business Network Intelligence dashboard to spot supplier-side delays and identify where discovery and onboarding take longest.

  •  

    Activate Quick Wins with High ROI

Once you‚Äôve diagnosed, move quickly to activate the features that shift gears fast.  Use Adoption Labs and Playbooks to train your team on these capabilities with real scenarios - Make it sticky.  Enable your top 2-3 high-impact levers:

  • Guided Sourcing for intuitive intake + template reuse.
  • Sourcing Library to standardize scoring criteria.
  • Full Projects for milestone-based rigor.
  • Supplier Discovery + Recommendations (powered by Joule AI).
  • eAuctions to compress price cycles by 20-50%.

Pro tip: Joule in Guided Sourcing can auto-recommend suppliers, templates, and event structures based on category patterns. Less manual config, more guided intelligence

  • Institutionalize, Benchmark, and Optimize

Change doesn‚Äôt stick unless it‚Äôs tracked and reinforced.  Measure performance monthly and celebrate momentum:

  • % of events using standard templates.
  • % of events completed within <11 days.
  • Savings per event.
  • FTEs per project manager.

Pro tip 1: Benchmark against top 25% performers from the SAP Benchmarking Program

Pro tip 2: Use SAP Best Practice Center to connect with peers, watch real implementation sessions, and bring in coaching for tough use cases.

Organizational Enablers: This Can‚Äôt Just Be a Tool Rollout

You also require alignment across:

  • Executive Sponsorship: They need to own the shift to sourcing speed + savings.
  • Program Vision: Tie cycle time directly to savings targets and supplier diversity.
  • Governance: Set KPIs, review cadence, unblock issues.
  • Change Comms: Explain the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind each enablement step to your buyers and approvers.

 

Final Word: It‚Äôs Not Just About Speed

Cutting sourcing cycle time is great.  But what you‚Äôre really unlocking is:

  • Faster savings realization.
  • More competitive supplier engagement.
  • Reduced sourcing fatigue for your team.
  • Increased compliance and transparency.

With the right combination of insight (Signavio), automation (Joule), and process governance (Guided Sourcing, Sourcing Library, eAuctions), your sourcing function can evolve from reactive firefighting to strategic acceleration.

 

If this series helped you rethink your sourcing model, feel free to drop a comment.

entry.title: Can SAP Help European CEOs Win in Times of Global Turbulence?
entry.content:
Article Teaser:
You‚Äôre leading amid change. Markets shift, regulations tighten, supply chains wobble. How can SAP help you stay ahead, make bold decisions and build resilience?

The New Reality for Leaders

Today, change hits fast. A supplier drops. A new regulation lands. Demand shifts overnight. As a European CEO or CTO, waiting for monthly reports won‚Äôt work. You need insight in real time.

Why the ERP Market Matters

The European ERP software market is expected to grow to about USD 36.35 billion in 2025, up from roughly USD 30.82 billion in 2024. 

In the EU, around 73 % of SMEs already reach a basic level of digital intensity, but many still lack high-value tools. 

What SAP Brings to The Table

  • Connected systems: Finance, supply chain, HR and operations talk to each other.
  • Live data insight: You get up-to-date dashboards, not stale reports.
  • Embedded intelligence & automation: SAP brings smart tools that handle routine tasks so your team focuses on strategic work.

Why This Matters to You

When everything is linked, you move faster, decide better, bounce back quicker. Supply disruptions, cost spikes, talent gaps, they still happen. But you‚Äôre ready.

A Scenario that Could Be Yours

Imagine this: You see a raw-material price jump. Your system alerts you immediately. You check supplier capacity, stock on hand, and cost impact. You update forecasts and pricing in hours, not days. That‚Äôs connected enterprise in action.

Actions for Leaders

  • Align your data: Make sure all teams define and use metrics the same way.
  • Set governance and trust: Know who uses what data, why, and how decisions are made.
  • Enable agility: Give your teams tools and permission to act quickly with insight.

Conclusion

Uncertainty is here to stay. Speed and insight matter more than ever. SAP gives you the foundation. You bring the leadership. Together, you turn change intoan  advantage.

Soft CTA:
If you‚Äôre ready to explore how SAP solutions can strengthen your leadership in turbulent times, join discussions in the SAP Community or connect with experts who guide change across Europe. Feel free to reach me at neel.panchal@stridelysolutions.com to learn more.

entry.title: Re: How to customize push notification payload to send additional data from s/4 to SSAM
entry.content: Hey @keithblake, did you use fiori to create notification? We tried creating notification from fiori using create maintenance request app and the push processing is executed before notification is saved. This is why we will not be able to fetch data from table in that method.

entry.title: Re: How to make ByDesign consider available stock from an...
entry.content: Hi Rathapol, In SAP Business ByDesign, for a product planning in a planning area, each time only one source can be determined. For your example, the way for system to consider the 1 ea available stock in AGRY0000 is, in the master data of this product, under tab Planning, select planning area AGHQ0000, select "Internal Procurement" (or "Source of Supply Priority Rule") for field "Procurement Type", while maintain a transport lane from site AGRY0000 to site AGHQ0000. When running MRP for this product in planning area AGHQ0000, system will create a stock transfer proposal with quantity 7 ea, it is a supply in planning area AGHQ0000, but a demand in planning area AGRY0000. Then, running MRP for this product in planning area AGRY0000, it will create another new stock transfer proposal (since its procurement type is also "Internal Procurement") with quantity 6 ea, since now there is only 1 ea available stock. System is unable to create stock transfer proposal with 1 ea from AGRY0000 to AGHQ0000, meanwhile create a purchase proposal with 6 ea in AGHQ0000. Because in this way system is looking for two sources of supply simultanously, this is not supported in ByD. Possible workaround: firstly create a stock transfer order manually to transfer the 1 ea from AGRY0000 to AGHQ0000, then run MRP in AGHQ0000 with "External Procurement" as "Procurement Type". Henry SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Build, Configure, and Deploy SAP CAP Projects to the Cloud
entry.content:
Hi @KlausPeng ,

If you developed using managed approuter you dont need to create a separate xs-app.json (as described in the guide),

The Fiori app‚Äôs deployment configuration (during wizard creation) already ensures:

  • The app is registered as an HTML5 application

  • The approuter discovers it from the HTML5 repo

    When do you actually need to create or edit xs-app.json?

    Only when using a standalone/custom approuter, where you must define explicit routes

    Yes @KlausPeng , I have tested the end-to-end deployment and tested it in BTP

entry.title: Re: Build, Configure, and Deploy SAP CAP Projects to the Cloud
entry.content:
Hi @KlausPeng ,Great to hear it worked ‚Äî thanks for confirming!

Regarding your next question:

Using HANA Cloud Data in a Custom UI5 App (with Managed Approuter)

Yes, you can fetch data from HANA Cloud and consume it inside your custom UI5 app ‚Äî but you should not call HANA Cloud directly from UI5.

 Why you cannot call HANA Cloud directly from UI5

Actually HANA Cloud does not expose OData directly, It only exposes SQL or HDI artifacts (tables, views).

You must expose the data via a CAP service (OData V2 or V4).

So the correct is:

HANA Cloud ‚Üí CAP Service (OData) ‚Üí Managed Approuter ‚Üí UI5 App

There maybe multiple approaches for this, but I followed this way and it works as it

Try this way, if you needs further clarifications will guide you.

entry.title: Re: Bill of Operation - SAP BYD
entry.content:
Hi Ephraim,

Since the fixed duration and variable duration in BoO is used to calculate how long time a production activity will take, and this time will be used for system to calculate many date and time in production, like Released Execution Model Explosion Date, Earliest Start, Latest Start, Earliest End, Latest End. In this calulation, operation hours in corresponding production site, and operation time of related resource are considered. Since both the two times are maintained with hour, like 09:00 - 17:00, hence we should also use hour for fixed duration and variable duration in BoO.

Actually you can maintain 24:00:00 (or any other time you prefer) to represent a day in duration, and 168:00:00 (or any other time you prefer) to represent a week in duration, etc.

Henry

SAP Support

entry.title: SAP Digital Battery Passport
entry.content:
The European Union‚Äôs Digital Battery Passport mandate is arriving soon!

Are you ready?

The EU is rolling out the Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation (ESPR) framework and Digital Product Passports (DPPs) to drive transparency, sustainability, and circularity across industries and make products durable, repairable, and resource-efficient.

A key feature of ESPR is the introduction of the Digital Product Passport (DPP)‚Äîa standardized, digital record that provides information about a product, including details on its materials, origins, repairability, recycling potential, and environmental impact.

DPP will be mandatory for the products covered by ESPR, with specific requirements set by product-specific delegated acts. The standard implementation window is at least 18 months after publication.

ESPR defines what sustainability information is required, and DPPs define how it is collected, verified, and shared.

SAP addresses both to offer their customers out of the box compliance.

By February 2027, all industrial batteries with a capacity greater than two kilowatt-hours must provide a Digital Battery Passport:

  • Portable batteries
  • SLI (starting, lightning and ignition)
  • LMT (Light means of transport)
  • EV (Electric Vehicles)
  • Industrial Batteries

While electric vehicle batteries are the most obvious category, many other battery-powered products will also require a passport. These include forklifts, renewable energy storage systems, mining and construction machinery, and the list goes on. Meanwhile, even though the regulation originates in Europe, its impact is global. That‚Äôs because any company wishing to sell battery-powered products within the European Union will need to comply, whether domiciled on the continent or overseas.

Give the implementation deadline of February 2027, the best time is begin preparing is now.
 
With this in mind, SAP is building a solution to help businesses turn the European Union‚Äôs Digital Battery Passport mandate into a competitive advantage. SAP delivers more than compliance ‚Äì it connects product data across the value chain to create a comprehensive digital history spanning origin, composition, carbon footprint and recycling data, all enriched by SAP‚Äôs end-to-end process coverage and collaboration.

SAP solution is a multi-passport platform powered by SAP Business Network for Asset Collaboration (SAP BNAC) and SAP Integrated Product Development (SAP IPD). The first product passport we‚Äôre supporting is the Digital Battery Passport, but there are more products covered by ESPR regulations.

SAP IPD acts as the product source for the product-level component of the passport, including its attributes, components and ingredients.

SAP BNAC Manages the collaborative component of the Digital Battery Passport, the instance specific attributes as well as creation and maintenance of digital product passports according to the EU regulations.

Our solution is:

  • Designed to fully comply with regulatory demands for the EU Digital Battery Passport, leveraging predefined and compliant templates, open standards, and an interoperable format.
  • Streamlined information exchange with customers, stakeholders and legal authorities, through seamless integration with business transactions and enterprise applications
  • Flexible and extensible platform that allows other emerging product passports, strong API support and a holistic approach across various industries

Outcomes:

  • Early compliance reduces future regulatory costs as similar rules expand globally
  • Trusted data will enable new business models across the entire lifecycle
  • Deep integration into SAP portfolio saves operational costs and manual effort, while streamlining decision-making
  • Become future-ready with scalable solutions that adapt as regulations evolve

Start preparing now!

entry.title: Re: Portugal settlement document number range is not in s...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because the document number and the digital signature reference number are technically two separate number range objects. Even if you manually sync them, the system treats them independently. During reversal, the system consumes the document number range (because a reversal document is created). But the digital signature number range is not consumed, because reversal documents typically don‚Äôt trigger a new digital signature. Hence, the NR status of the digital signature remains unchanged. After reversal, the next settlement document pulls the next document number (correctly), but the reference field still points to the unchanged digital signature NR, causing the misalignment.

Check the below areas to fix this

Verify in Basic Functions ‚Üí Number Range Assignment whether the reference field is explicitly tied to the digital signature NR object. If so, this is standard behavior ‚Äî the reference field will always follow the digital signature NR, regardless of the settlement NR.

Check if the digital signature number range is intended to be independent. In many implementations, it is not supposed to be identical to the settlement document number. If business requires them to match, you‚Äôll need a custom enhancement or exit to align them.

Confirm whether reversals are supposed to generate a digital signature entry. If not, then the mismatch is expected. If business requires reversals to consume the digital signature NR, you‚Äôll need to adjust the reversal logic (via BAdI or user exit).

entry.title: Re: Specify an internal interval (Message no. NR752) - WB...
entry.content:
Why you see the error is because, when you create/assign a WBS without transferring plan values, the system only needs the WBS number range (which is already configured). When you transfer plan values from the Appropriation Request to the WBS, the system also tries to create Investment Program Position / Budget objects in the background. These objects require internal number ranges to be defined in customizing. If the internal interval is missing, you get NR752.

Check the below areas:

Go to SPRO ‚Üí Investment Management ‚Üí Appropriation Requests ‚Üí Maintain Number Ranges. Ensure that for the appropriation request type you are using, both external and internal intervals are defined. The error means the internal interval is missing.

Check Appropriation Request Type ‚Üí Number Range Assignment. Make sure the type you are using is linked to a valid number range object with internal interval.

If plan values are being transferred, the system may also try to create budget supplement/return documents. Verify that number ranges for budget documents (IM) are defined in SPRO ‚Üí Investment Management ‚Üí Budgeting ‚Üí Maintain Number Ranges for Budget Documents.

entry.title: Deploying SAP Cloud Connector on AWS Free Tier Using Terraform and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server
entry.content:
Setting up the SAP Cloud Connector traditionally involves several manual steps: preparing a virtual machine, installing the required runtime components, configuring system services, and opening the correct network paths. In this guide, the entire process is streamlined by using Terraform and a lightweight SUSE Linux instance on AWS. With a fully automated installer script and a small set of IaC templates, you can deploy a Cloud Connector in just a few minutes. This approach is ideal for sandboxes, learning environments, and rapid prototyping on the AWS Free Tier.

1. Prerequisites

  • AWS account with permissions to create EC2 instances, S3 buckets, and security groups
  • Basic Linux shell usage skills (SSH, simple commands, log inspection)
  • Terraform installed locally
  • SSH client (OpenSSH, PuTTY, etc.)
  • A free-tier compatible SUSE Linux Enterprise Server AMI (x86_64) in your chosen region
  • An existing EC2 key pair (placeholder: <YOUR_KEY_PAIR_NAME>)
  • An S3 bucket containing the SCC ZIP file, for example:
<YOUR_S3_BUCKET_NAME>/sapcc-2.16.2-linux-x64.zip

Note: Direct downloads of the SCC installer from tools.hana.ondemand.com do not work with wget or curl. These commands will return an HTML page instead of the actual ZIP file, even though the filename looks correct.

file sapcc-2.16.2-linux-x64.zip

If the output shows HTML document instead of Zip archive, the download has been redirected and is unusable. Hosting the installer in your own S3 bucket ensures the Terraform automation can download it reliably.

2. Terraform Configuration

The following main.tf provisions:

  • A SUSE Linux Enterprise Server EC2 instance on AWS Free Tier
  • A security group exposing ports 22 (SSH) and 8443 (SCC UI)
  • A startup script (install-scc.sh) that installs and configures SAP Cloud Connector

Project Directory Structure

A working directory named terraform_scc was created to hold the Terraform configuration and installation script:

terraform_scc/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.tf                 # Terraform infrastructure definition
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ install-scc.sh          # SCC installation and tuning script
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ outputs.tf              # Terraform output definitions (optional)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ variables.tf            # Variable declarations (optional)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md               # Optional notes or setup instructions

Only main.tf and install-scc.sh are required. The remaining files are optional but commonly included for structure and clarity.

2.1 main.tf

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.5"

  required_providers {
    aws = {
      source  = "hashicorp/aws"
      version = "~> 5.0"
    }
  }
}

provider "aws" {
  region = "us-east-2"
}

resource "aws_security_group" "sap_scc_sg" {
  name        = "sap-scc-sg"
  description = "Allow SCC UI and SSH"
  vpc_id      = "<YOUR_VPC_ID>"

  ingress {
    from_port   = 22
    to_port     = 22
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  ingress {
    from_port   = 8443
    to_port     = 8443
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  egress {
    from_port   = 0
    to_port     = 0
    protocol    = "-1"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }
}

resource "aws_instance" "sap_scc" {
  ami           = "ami-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"   # SLES x86_64 AMI in your region
  instance_type = "t2.micro"                # Free tier compatible
  key_name      = "<YOUR_KEY_PAIR_NAME>"

  subnet_id                   = "<YOUR_SUBNET_ID>"
  associate_public_ip_address = true

  vpc_security_group_ids = [
    aws_security_group.sap_scc_sg.id
  ]

  user_data = file("${path.module}/install-scc.sh")

  tags = {
    Name = "SAP-Cloud-Connector-SLES"
  }
}

output "public_ip" {
  value = aws_instance.sap_scc.public_ip
}

2.2 Running Terraform

# Initialize Terraform
terraform init

# Optional: preview infrastructure changes
terraform plan

# Deploy SCC VM and networking
terraform apply -auto-approve

# Retrieve public IP for SCC access
terraform output -raw public_ip

# Destroy when finished
terraform destroy -auto-approve

3. Installation Script (install-scc.sh)

This script installs SAP Cloud Connector on SUSE Linux Enterprise Server, tunes the JVM for t2.micro memory limits, enables the systemd daemon, and waits for SCC to start listening on port 8443.

Note: Replace <YOUR_S3_BUCKET_NAME> with your own bucket name.

#!/bin/bash
set -euxo pipefail

SCC_VERSION="2.16.2"
SCC_FILE="sapcc-${SCC_VERSION}-linux-x64.zip"

S3_BUCKET="<YOUR_S3_BUCKET_NAME>"
SCC_URL="https://${S3_BUCKET}.s3.amazonaws.com/${SCC_FILE}"

LOG_FILE="/var/log/scc-install.log"

exec > >(tee -a "${LOG_FILE}") 2>&1

echo "=== SAP Cloud Connector install on SLES ==="
echo "Version: ${SCC_VERSION}"
echo "Source:  ${SCC_URL}"

echo "=== Installing prerequisites ==="
zypper -n refresh
zypper -n install curl unzip java-11-openjdk-headless || zypper -n install java-17-openjdk-headless

cd /tmp

echo "=== Downloading SCC ==="
curl -L -o "${SCC_FILE}" "${SCC_URL}"

echo "=== Verifying ==="
file "${SCC_FILE}" | grep -qi "Zip" || exit 1

echo "=== Extracting ==="
rm -rf /tmp/scc-installer
mkdir /tmp/scc-installer
unzip -o "${SCC_FILE}" -d /tmp/scc-installer

cd /tmp/scc-installer

RPM=$(ls com.sap.scc-ui-*.rpm | head -n 1)

echo "=== Installing SCC RPM ==="
zypper -n --no-gpg-checks install "./${RPM}"

echo "=== Tuning heap for t2.micro ==="
if [ -f /opt/sap/scc/props.ini ]; then
  cp /opt/sap/scc/props.ini /opt/sap/scc/props.ini.bak || true
  sed -i 's/-Xms1024m/-Xms256m/g; s/-Xmx1024m/-Xmx512m/g; \
          s/-XX:MaxNewSize=512m/-XX:MaxNewSize=256m/g; \
          s/-XX:NewSize=512m/-XX:NewSize=256m/g' /opt/sap/scc/props.ini
fi

echo "=== Starting SCC service ==="
systemctl enable scc_daemon.service
systemctl restart scc_daemon.service

echo "=== Waiting for port 8443 ==="
for i in {1..12}; do
  if ss -tulpn | grep -q 8443; then
    echo "SCC is up"
    break
  fi
  echo "Attempt $i/12: 8443 not listening yet, sleeping 10s..."
  sleep 10
done

echo "=== Done ==="

4. Verifying the Deployment

SSH Access

ssh -i <YOUR_KEY_PAIR_NAME> ec2-user@<public-ip>

Check SCC Status

sudo systemctl status scc_daemon.service
ss -tulpn | grep 8443

5. Accessing the SCC UI

Once the SAP Cloud Connector service has started on your SUSE instance, open the administration UI in your browser.

https://<YOUR_PUBLIC_IP>:8443

You will be redirected to the login page:

The default credentials on first login are:

User: Administrator
Password: manage

After logging in, you will be prompted to set a new password.

6. Connect the SCC to BTP

Once authenticated, the landing screen indicates that no subaccount is currently configured.

Navigate to Connector ‚Üí Define Subaccount and enter the following details:

  • Region Code (example: us10)
  • Subaccount ID (GUID from BTP Cockpit)
  • Display Name (any label of your choice)
  • Subaccount User (your BTP email)
  • Password (IAS/BTP password)

Save the configuration. The connector will establish a secure tunnel within a few seconds.

7. Successful Connection

Once connected, the overview section will update and display the Connection Status, Subaccount Certificate, and Tunnel ID:

Your Cloud Connector is now fully operational and ready for use. You can proceed with exposing your on-premise resources to SAP BTP via Cloud To On-Premise ‚Üí Access Control.

8. Observations and Considerations

  • SCC‚Äôs default heap settings exceed the memory available on t2.micro instances; tuning is required for reliable startup.
  • In production environments, restrict SSH and SCC UI access to trusted IP ranges.
  • The installation process is ideal for training, PoCs, and labs where lightweight automation is needed.
  • Using Terraform ensures fast, repeatable provisioning and clean teardown.
  • While t2.micro instances and standard gp3 storage sit within AWS‚Äôs Free Tier, using SUSE or other licensed AMIs can incur hourly charges under certain circumstances, even on t2.micro. Double-check your AMI selection to avoid unexpected billing.

entry.title: Enabling Joule on multiple SAP SuccessFactors instances
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am seeking clarification regarding the enablement of the Joule license on multiple SAP SuccessFactors instances (e.g., Test, Dev, and Prod).

From the SAP documentation, I understand that:

- "To set up a Joule Preview tenant, subaccounts must be in the EU10 or EU30 data centers; otherwise, it is not possible to add Joule Preview entitlements."
- "A single Joule subscription can be integrated with multiple SAP products but only with one tenant per product. Therefore, it is not possible to use a single Joule subscription across multiple tenants of the same product."


I would like to know:

1) If a subaccount is not located in the EU10 or EU30 data centers, how can Joule be enabled in Test or Preview environments?
2) Considering the requirement to enable Joule on three SAP SuccessFactors instances (Test, Dev, and Prod), how can this be achieved? Is it possible to use the Joule service on multiple instances? What is the recommended approach in such cases?

Thank you in advance to anyone who can provide guidance or share experiences on this topic.

entry.title: Positioning SAP Business Data cloud on SAP Business Technology Platform : Clearing the Confusion
entry.content:
As we all know, with digital transformation and the move toward cloud mindset, clean core, fit-to-standard, and fit-to-suite, the shift to cloud-based business solutions keeps growing. Many of us remember the term introduced around 2011 when the HANA database was introduced  the SAP Business Intelligence portfolio. Over time, this evolved to BW on HANA, BW/4HANA, and then the ERP transition from ECC to S/4HANA.

From my understanding, this Business Intelligence portfolio or SAP BI Suite has also evolved with the adoption of the cloud platform. Now we hear the term SAP Business Suite, which I think is similar to the earlier BI Suite which acts like an umbrella covering the core enterprise applications. This newer SAP Business Suite connects different areas of the business using SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Data Cloud, all running on top of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

SAP BTP is known as a platform-as-a-service used to design, build, deploy, and manage end-to-end applications in the cloud. It provides the foundation for integrating, extending, and innovating across SAP and non-SAP systems, so business processes remain connected, flexible, and intelligent.

We are also familiar with the fact that we can view all the services available on BTP through the SAP Discovery Center under different capability areas: App Development, Integration, Data & Analytics and Artificial Intelligence.

If you go to the Discovery Center and look under Data & Analytics, you will see SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere listed there. But when you go to the BTP Cockpit and try to create a service for these applications, you won‚Äôt find them.

And that‚Äôs exactly where the confusion started for me. Because they appear under BTP capabilities, the expectation is that we should be able to create them as services.
But we can‚Äôt and this is where SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) comes into the picture.

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud is a SaaS business solution suite built on top of BTP. It uses the underlying BTP data and analytics capabilities like Datasphere and SAC.

To simplify:

  • BDC is not replacing BTP ‚Äî it runs on top of it.
  • BDC is a packaged business solution, not a developer service.
  • You cannot create BDC service on BTP like you create HANA Cloud or Integration Suite.
  • BDC has its own onboarding and tenant provisioning process.

In short, BTP is the platform, and BDC is the ready-to-use data and analytics solution built on that platform.

The next question that popped into my mind, since we cannot create them as services or subscriptions via BTP, how do we access them? We still have a standalone SAC tenant , a standalone Datasphere tenant and we could switch between them easily by linking the tenants. This still works the same.

What changed now is that SAP now sells this as a packaged solution under BDC.
Instead of separate licenses for SAC and Datasphere, BDC combines them into one SaaS package and just one license.

So BTP remains the platform under the hood, while BDC provides the SAAS packaged solution but it is not a BTP service. It has its own onboarding, which I‚Äôll cover in my next blog.

entry.title: Integrate Tax Payment Receipt (CFDI) into SuccessFactors employee profile
entry.content:
Hello, thank you to the community for your contributions.

We are currently working successfully with SAP SuccessFactors and SAP Payroll.

We have been processing payroll and issuing electronic invoices with the EDICOM PAC without any issues.

However, in recent days, the need has arisen to integrate the electronically invoiced payslip into the employee profile.

Initially, we considered a solution where the files would be uploaded to the SAP SFTP space and imported into custom objects using templates.

Later, we found this blog post that describes the process of uploading attachments and then linking the attachment to the employee. This works quite well, as we would have the information organized for each employee in their profile, along with the history of electronically invoiced payslips in a custom portlet.

https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/upsert-custom-mdf-attachment-via-odata/ba-p/13411450

However, before deciding how to integrate these receipts, I'd like to know if there's a standard solution that makes this process more transparent and simpler. Both options I mentioned earlier require a middleware to handle all the integration logic.

With this in mind, I'd like to know if there's a pre-developed solution we could use and implement.

A licensing fee is not a concern.

Thank you all for your support.

entry.title: Settings for Budget / Planned Cost Transfer to PS Project and Actual Cost Rollup to PPM Objects
entry.content:
Introduction: In this article, I aim to cover the necessary configuration settings for the financial data flow between Portfolio and Project Management (PPM) and Controlling (CO) objects, such as Work Breakdown Structure elements (WBS). I believe this information will be valuable for all EPPM consultants, particularly those who are beginners looking to learn and advance in the SAP EPPM area.

Settings for Budget / Planned Cost Transfer to PS Project and Actual Cost Rollup to PPM Objects:

I am going to cover the key important settings in configuration for Budget / Planned Cost Transfer from PPM Item to linked PS Project and Actual Cost rollup from PS Project to PPM Item, Initiative and Bucket.

Prerequisites: Settings for Automatic PS Project creation is already in place, you may refer my another article for the same as mentioned below:

For PPM Item to PS Project:

https://community.sap.com/t5/product-lifecycle-management-blog-posts-by-members/configuration-settings-for-automatic-ps-project-creation-from-ppm-item/ba-p/14265007

For PPM Item to Project Management Project and further PS Project from cProject:

https://community.sap.com/t5/product-lifecycle-management-blog-posts-by-members/settings-for-the-automatic-creation-of-cproject-from-a-ppm-item-followed-by/ba-p/14262460

For Financial Planning and Integration in PPM, Financial Category, Group and Views need to be defined, by default SAP has provided these in standard which you may modify or replace with your own Category, Group and Views as per business needs and requirements.

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management ‚Äì Portfolio Management ‚Äì Global Customizing ‚Äì Portfolio-Independent Settings ‚Äì Define Financial and Capacity Categories

Groups under category material:

Below mentioned configuration node is very important in terms of the Views where you actually configure which view need to be updated manually in PPM Item or which need to be updated automatically from PS Project.

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management ‚Äì Portfolio Management - Global Customizing ‚Äì Portfolio-Independent Settings ‚Äì Define Financial and Capacity Views

Here, we will mainly focus on Planned Costs and Actual Cost, Planned Costs I am going keep as Manual update in PPM Item and Actual as Integration for PS Project to PPM Item

 

Here, View 5 ‚Äì Planned Costs we kept as Manual and ‚ÄúAmount Type for Transfer‚Äù as ‚Äú0 Budget Transfer‚Äù that means, the Planned Costs updated manually in PPM Item will be transferred as Budget in associated PS Project, if you wish to transfer this as Planned Cost in PS Project instead of Budget, you may select another option "1 Planned Cost Transfer". Actual Cost as ‚ÄúIntegration‚Äù that means it will be rolled up from PS Project to PPM Item, CO Version need to be updated as 0 to have the current real time value.

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management ‚Äì Portfolio Management ‚Äì Global Customizing ‚Äì Portfolio-Independent Settings ‚Äì Define Financial and Capacity View for Front-End Configuration

In this configuration node, we map all the views with the respective Financial Categories:

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management ‚Äì Portfolio Management ‚Äì Global Customizing ‚Äì Portfolio-Dependent Settings ‚Äì Define Financial Capacity Settings for Portfolio Types

In this node, mainly you need to link Financial Categories, Views and Activate Change documents for Financial Planning.

Here, you may add or remove views as per your business needs. NPV indicator needs to be set if current view type to be included when system calculates Net Present Value.

Mapping of Financial Views to Cost Elements

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management ‚Äì Portfolio Management ‚Äì Base System Interfaces ‚Äì Financial Planning Settings ‚Äì Define Financial Planning Settings

Note: This configuration needs to be done in the respective client such as Test or Production by opening the system.

Mapping of Cost Element is important for financial data flow and is applicable only for Integration scenario, since in this article we are mainly focusing on Manual Planned cost update and Integration of Actual cost, we will see the configuration settings maintained for Actual Cost.

Maintain the logical system, Controlling Area and Value Type 04 for Actual Cost.

Maintain the Cost Element group or Cost Element for each type of Views.

Note: Please be cautious while maintaining cost elements within the group. If a specific cost element appears in multiple cost element groups say for example in two groups and, for example, an actual cost of INR 10,000 is posted against that cost element, the PPM item will reflect an actual cost of INR 20,000 due to the duplication of the cost element across two different groups.

Maintain the CO version 0.

Let‚Äôs test the scenario:

Initiative FDTI01 created:

Item FDT-001 created under Initiative FDTI01

Manual Financial Planning done in Item as Planned Cost:

PS Project FDT-001 created automatically under Item:

We can see the Project in Project Builder too:

Currently there is no Budget in the PS Project.

Let‚Äôs transfer the Budget from PPM Item to PS Project:

Click on ‚ÄúTransfer to Project System‚Äù from Financial Planning page:

Select the line, select ‚ÄúTransfer‚Äù check box and click on ‚ÄúOK‚Äù, you should get the success message as shown below:

Now, let‚Äôs check in the PS Project:

We can see the status BUDG is updated, that means Project is Budgeted now, lets see in the Budget Display transaction:

Transaction Code: CJ31

Now we will post the actual Cost on WBS Element, to post the actual cost on WBS Element, the status of WBS must be Released.

Posted 10000 cost on WBS FDT-001 with Cost Element 51100000:

Now, let‚Äôs transfer the cost to PPM Item from PS Project:

Execute the Program /RPM/FICO_INT_PLANNING in transaction SE38 or SA38

Uncheck Test Mode checkbox, select radio button ‚ÄúIntegr.,Planning and Rollup‚Äù and update Destination as NONE by manually typing into the field.

Enter the Item ID and Cost Version as 0 and execute.

You will get the messages as shown below:

Now let‚Äôs check in the PPM Item and Initiative:

We can see the Actual Cost is updated automatically in Financial Planning page of Item:

Here the Cost are visible under Group Machines because the Cost Element used for actual cost posting is being maintained in the Cost Element Group assigned to Financial Group Machines.

In Initiative also Actual Cost Rolled up:

Conclusion: By reading this article and applying the settings in the system, you will be able to configure the essential settings for the financial data flow between PPM objects and CO objects, as well as in the reverse direction.

SAP Portfolio and Project Management SAP Portfolio and Project Management for SAP S/4HANA PLM Project System (PS)

entry.title: TMS on SAP Integration Suite for API proxy transports in SAP API Management
entry.content:
Purpose

Moving API proxies between different tenants can be a critical step in your development lifecycle. This article provides a clear, step-by-step guide on how to successfully set up the Transport Management System (TMS) to handle API proxy transports, building on the assumption that you already have TMS configured for your Integrations. 

Prerequisites
Before beginning the setup, ensure the following entitlement is available in both your source (e.g., Development) and destination (e.g., Production) subaccounts:

  • API Management, API portal

Process
Step:1: Create a service instance for the API Management, API portal entitlement using the apiportal-apiaccess plan. This needs to be done in both your source and destination subaccounts

 

Step:2: For the instances created in Step 1, generate a service key in both the source and destination subaccounts. Crucially, ensure you copy and securely store both service keys, as they contain the credentials and URLs required for the following steps.

Step:3: In the Connectivity section of the Cockpit for your source subaccount, create a new Destination (From Scratch). This destination will allow your source environment to connect and push transports to the destination environment. The details that is used in configuring this destination is from the service key details of destination environment (Production in my case)

 

ParametersValues
NameAPIManagement
AuthenticationOAuth2ClientCredentials
TypeHTTP
Client IDFrom Destination JSON Key File
Client SecretFrom Destination JSON Key File
Token Service URLFrom Destination JSON key file
URL{{ URL from Destination JSON key File}}/api/1.0/transportmodule/Transport
Token Service URL TypeDedicated

Step:4: Once the destination configuration is complete, you should be able to initiate the transport of API proxies (and API Providers) from your source tenant. A new Transport Request (TR) will be generated and visible in your Cloud Transport Management System.

You should be finding this TR in your Transport Request of Transport Management System.

Problems faced

If any of the below errors are encountered when initiating the transport, check the destination configuration in source subaccount / tenant (Step:3). All the above errors are due to incorrect destination configuration. Check if you have the correct destination name, correct URL in destination configured (destination service key URL with path /api/1.0/transportmodule/Transport), correct credentials (destination service key credential)



Transport request has failed as the destination APIManagement is not correctly configured. Details: Destination configuration error in APIManagement . Bad credentials sap apim
Transport request has failed as the destination APIManagement is not correctly configured. Details: Validation failed as destination APIManagement not configured with correct URL

If the below error is encountered, then the integration artifact that this API represents / linked is not actually present in destination tenant or subaccount. First transport the corresponding integration artifacts first then transport the API artifact.

The artifact you're attempting to transport could not be found or has encountered an error. Please verify that the artifact exists and try again. If the problem continues, contact SAP Support for assistance

Result

If you have all the pre-requisite complete along with the above steps, we should readily be able to do the API Proxy transports, API Provider transports from source subaccounts to destination subaccounts. Once you click transport from the source, it should create a transport ID and a transport request that can be seen in Cloud TMS with the API details.
